Description: Mould-made scaraboid in glazed composition. Back in form of well-modelled Black African head with small wide apart eyes, short broad nose and thick lips; diaper pattern hair on top of head with hairline naturalistically shown, curved down across forehead, and then swept back at sides; ears with dot in middle. Underside decorated with representation of winged sphinx walking to right, wearing four-feathered headdress and with protruding ears (Bes-headed sphinx?); device possibly stamped into damp material. Laterally pierced above ears for suspension. Scarce remains of yellowish glaze on some of face and hair; core yellow in colour.
Curator's comments: Winged mythological creatures are commonly depicted on scarabs and scaraboids at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). This piece belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-103, 106-107, Type XXVIII A, subtype A116-117, but see A114 for this piece wrongly identified as a Bes head scaraboid). The features of the Black African head compare with moulds found in the Factory, of which Petrie only illustrated four types (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, 8-11, see especially type 9 for this piece). See also BM 1888,0601.56 / EA66523 (Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 55) with a similar 'Bes-headed sphinx' device represented on the underside of a scaraboid in blue paste. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, Type XXVIII A114) (but not a Bes head)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.067) (phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Commitee of)
